instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Hi All!
Got this board stuck on 5v - 0,34 amp not switching to 20v. 
Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> because it gets very hot when charger is connected.
Now the board is freezed at 5v - 0.03 amp.
All the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> seems to work fine, all the LDO lines are stable at 1,80v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> =5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>=3,4

Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> not switched on.
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL>=0v               
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q2</SIGNAL>=0v
L7030 Pin 1=0V

So the problem in ISL 9239 am I right?
I don't have a donor and i don't have the ic right now, so while i'm buying it and wait for delivery there's something that i can do to sort out the problem?
Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
"[B][U]all[/U][/B] the LDO lines are stable at 1,80v"
Should start clarifying this; there are 1V1 and 3V3 LDOs too!

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode to ground at F7000.

What about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and USB-C inputs when battery and charger are both connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
diode mode to ground at F7000= 0.434
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>=5,18v
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>=1,29v
VDDA=4,99v
VDDP=4,99v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>=3,4v
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>=3,4v

When battery+Charger connected.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> come up at 12,50v
And USB-C goes 20v but 0amp

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
So you have a problem on USB-C areas; don't switch to 20V without battery.
All USB-C ports have the same behavior (without battery)?
Check each one on both connection ways.

When battery is connected, any reaction pressing power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Ok so let's do a Recap because I'm really confused right now.
Something has changed, maybe I've done a mistake yesterday night i was really tired. Anyway... now this is the situation:

Macbook now is working on battery. When I open the lid it power up and boots normally.
Two ports on the same side drain 20v 0amp in all positions.
The other side isn't working at all. the usb-c meter doesn't even lights up.
No way to charge macbook in this situation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
I'll check again all LDO lines meanwhile.
Also power button is not responding. Touch id is working flawlessy

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
OK so let's do a RECAP because I'm really confused right now.

WITHOUT BATTERY CONNECTED:
All 4 USB ports in all position drain 5v , 0,03 amp. 

WITH BATTERY CONNECTED:
Macbook powers on when I open lid. Power button is unresponsive, touch id works.
USB-C on the left side report 20v, 0 amp in all positions.
USB-C on the other side doesn't even light up the USB meter.
No way to charge macbook.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
So your problem is USB-C related; rest of the board works.

Check ALL LDOs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Be aware, 1V1 LDO appears ONLY on the powered port at time.
Also compare diode mode to ground readings between all ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message: For the LDO's measurements I assume with battery disconnected , right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>             0,518    1,79
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>             0,484    1,79
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>           0,51 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Then you have a problem on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 area.
Did you replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with correct <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> version?
Inspect <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> traces and resistors for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
CD3215C00 that comes from a store, Not donor.I have 3 more and i can pull one from a donor <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> seems fine. All resistor are Ok ohm value.
Get 3,3v on pin 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
I've also checked J3300 and JB500 diode mode reading, everything is OK according to logikiwi EXCEPT pin 23 on J3300
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_USB_BOT_N</SIGNAL> measure 1.010 in diode mode instead of OL.

Edit: fixed by changing diode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Back again on this board after a busy week.
so <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> did not get to 1,1v when adapter is connected. 
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> is missing clock. I don't have an oscilloscope but the measurement on Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R3095</RESISTOR> stays stable at 0,2v.

On the other side, on pin 1 of RB280 i have 1,1v but I see "movement" on the lower bar of multimeter and it looks more similar to a "working" clock signal.

Why I don't get proper clock on <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>? Looking at schematics seems that clock is generated from <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> pin 3 right? Not from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>...
I've already replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> twice and I checked trace between pin 3 of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R3095</RESISTOR>.. my measure is 1,8ohm.. is this acceptable or i need pure 0ohm?

Thank you in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Multimeter leads resistance enters there too; 1-2 ohm is good reading.

There must be a problem with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200, or surrounding components.
Compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 with UB300/400 area.
There may be bad resistor, broken trace...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v Stuck
threads.message:
Late post for an already solved board issue. I forgot to reply last time...
Just to share my experience with the forum, maybe can help someone in the future.

Issue was simple.
Fake/not working CD321500C chips.
Bought them from a thrusted seller, i've already bought those in the past from this guy. Never had issues before. 

After spending days wondering why <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> stays 0v even with charger connected.... I replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> left side from donor board and voilà... 
motherboard now works flawlessy.

With the crappy chips all others LDO voltage were fine, and also diode mode readings ... That's why I get caught up.
I tried 5 of them , same problem. Throw directly to the bin.

Thanks anyway for your time.
